questions.question: Question 1: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of:
questions.explanation:
Reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of obstructive lung disease. Forced vital capacity (FVC) is the volume of expired air recorded when a person inhales to the 
total lung capacity and exhales as hard and as completely as possible. The volume of air expired in 
the first second is called the forced expiratory volume 1 (FEV1). Given below is a graphical representation of FEV and FEV1: FVC is reduced in both obstructive and restrictive lung diseases. In obstructive diseases, the slope 
of FVC is steady, therefore the FEV1 value is low and the FEV1/FVC ratio decreases. In restrictive 
diseases, the airflow is fast in the beginning leading to a higher value of FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio 
increases.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 66-year-old smoker presented with chronic productive cough and shortness of breath. 
Physical examination revealed a barrel chest and an expiratory wheeze on auscultation. All of 
the following findings would be seen in his pulmonary function tests except?
questions.explanation:
654 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is 
characterized by an increased residual volume. According to Uptodate, decreased vital capacity and increased total lung capacity is indicative of 
hyperinflation seen in COPD. FVC can be used a proxy for VC in normal individuals but in COPD 
FVC is less than VC due to air trapping, airflow limitation, and small airway collapse.

questions.question:
Question 3: An 8-year-old boy presents with intermittent wheeze and cough. His mother reports that 
these episodes are precipitated by physical exercise. There is a history of atopic dermatitis in 
his mother. Pulmonary function tests are performed. Which of the following findings are least 
likely to be seen in him?

options.a: Decreased forced expiratory volume in one second

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of asthma. The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon 
monoxide (DLCO) tends to be normal or high in these patients.

questions.question:
Question 4: 649 
Sold by @itachibot Decreased maximum mid-expiratory flow rate is seen in obstruction of:
questions.explanation:
Decreased maximum mid-expiratory flow rate (MMFR) is seen in obstruction of small airways. MMFR is the average expiratory flow rate during the middle 50% of the vital capacity i.e., forced 
expiratory flow rate between 25 and 75% of the vital capacity. This is the most sensitive measurement of early airflow obstruction, particularly in small airways.

questions.question:
Question 5: Patients with which of the following conditions is likely to have pulmonary function test 
findings as given below:
questions.explanation:
Low FEV1 and FVC with a high FEV1/FVC ratio are characteristics of restrictive lung disease. 
Among the options, pleural effusion is a restrictive lung disease. • Obstructive lung diseases • Asthma • COPD • Bronchiectasis • Bronchiolitis • Restrictive lung diseases • Intrinsic • Interstitial lung disease • Extrinsic • Myasthenia gravis • Kyphoscoliosis • Pleural effusion 655

questions.question:
Question 6: A 76-year-old retired worker from a granite quarry presents with progressive dyspnea and a 
chronic cough. He has never smoked cigarettes. His chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the 
following patterns would you see on his pulmonary function tests?
questions.explanation:
The chest X-ray shows calcification of the hilar lymph nodes called eggshell calcification. The 
clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray is suggestive of silicosis. It is a restrictive lung disease 
characterized by increased FEV1/FVC and decreased compliance. It is an occupational interstitial lung disease.

questions.question:
Question 7: An elderly woman presents with breathlessness on exertion. On auscultation, bilateral basal 
rales are heard. A chest CT is done and is shown below. Which of the following is likely to be 
increased in her?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the honeycomb pattern of lung parenchyma due to 
interstitial fibrosis is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). The alveolar-arterial gradient 
(PAO2-PaO2) is increased in ILD. It is a restrictive lung disease. In ILD, the alveolar-capillary bed is damaged and thus there is a decrease in diffusion capacity. 
Therefore, while the PAO2 (Alveolar O2) remains normal, the PaO2 (arterial) decreases, and the 
alveolar-arterial difference increases.

questions.question: Question 8: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide is decreased in patients with:
questions.explanation:
Diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is decreased in patients with 
emphysema. DLCO measures the ability of the lungs to transfer gas from inhaled air in the alveoli to the red 
blood cells in pulmonary capillaries. In general, the DLCO is used to identify the cause of dyspnea or hypoxemia. It is also used 
to monitor disease progression in interstitial lung disease, and identify pulmonary hypertension in 
patients at risk, such as those with systemic sclerosis. DLCO is decreased in patients with: 656 
Sold by @itachibot • Interstitial lung disease • Emphysema (COPD usually have normal DLCO) • Bronchiolitis obliterans • Pulmonary hypertension • Thromboembolic disease • Chronic congestive Heart Failure DLCO is increased in patients with: • Alveolar hemorrhage • Acute Congestive heart failure • Asthma

questions.question:
Question 9: 651 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and fatigue. She has a medical history 
of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Her pulmonary function test results are given below. 
What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above PFT pattern shows near-normal FVC, increased FEV1%, and markedly decreased 
DLCO. This along with the given history is suggestive of pulmonary artery hypertension(PAH). It 
is more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Option B: Interstitial lung disease is a restrictive lung disease. In ILD, the FVC is usually,<80% 
of the predicted value. It is more commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Options C and D: Congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis have obstructive pathology. They 
would have decreased FEV1% and normal DLCO.

questions.question:
Question 10: A flow-volume loop of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? 652 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The likely diagnosis is tracheal stenosis. The flow-volume loop shows flattened inspiratory and 
expiratory curves, suggestive of fixed upper-airway obstruction. 657 
Sold by @itachibot A normal flow-volume loop begins on the X-axis (Volume axis): at the start of the test, both flow 
and volume are equal to zero. After the starting point, the curve rapidly mounts to a peak: Peak 
expiratory flow (PEF). Then, the PEF the curve descends (=the flow decreases) as more air is expired. A normal, 
non-pathological F/V loop will descend in a straight or a convex line from the top (PEF) to the 
bottom (FVC). The forced inspiration that follows the forced expiration has roughly the same morphology, but 
the PIF (Peak Inspiratory Flow) is not as distinct as PEF.

questions.question:
Question 11: The flow-volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis 
in this patient is:

options.a: Up to 40% of cardiac output may be distributed to the respiratory muscles
options.b: Patient will develop type 2 respiratory failure
options.c: Intubation and mechanical ventilation are treatment of choice
options.d: Batwing appearance can be expected on an x-ray

questions.explanation:
The given flow-volume curve shows decreased lung volumes (total lung capacity, vital capacity, 
and residual volume) with normal shape, suggestive of a restrictive pattern. The curve is a 
miniature version of the normal curve with shift towards the right. It is seen in myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis presents with ventilatory restriction due to reduced respiratory muscle 
strength. Asthma, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasms present with obstructive flow patterns. 658
